Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration: This project aims to develop a comprehensive approach for characterization of RF environment in terms of spatial and temporal features including: i) the number of active transmitters, ii) their power, direction of arrival and location, and iii) modulation class. Spatio-temporal spectrum sensing requires novel multi-dimensional parameter estimation algorithms as opposed to conventional spectrum sensing that uses hypothesis testing based detection algorithms. In this work, the Bayesian estimation approach using angle-of-arrival measurements is applied to create the probabilistic map of the transmitter presence in a given region taking into account measurement noise and uncertainties. The tools from random matrix theory are applied to perform joint detection and parameter estimation, and analytically derive performance bounds. The methods for modulation classification are based on goodness-of-fit statistical tests with reduced sampling complexity, and provide the unified classification framework for a wide range of modulation classes. The results of this research will impact the design of novel medium access and routing protocols that manage the interference through awareness of the location and link quality of other transmitters in the region. The developed technologies could potentially apply for monitoring of RF transmissions within wireless infrastructure, and for the defense and national security applications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spectrum sensing and measurement is increasingly recognized as a vital component in virtually all future wireless communication architecture.  Traditionally, spectrum sensing approaches are conducted in frequency domain using conventional detection methods. In this project, we aimed to explore spectrum sensing capabilities that characterize the RF behavior in an environment of interest as a function of time, space, and frequency. The proposed framework was named spatio-temporal spectrum sensing. As a result, we developed a set of  algorithms and network architectures that analyze spectrum occupancy by estimating: i) the number of active transmitters, ii) their power, direction of arrival and location, iii) traffic distribution and iv) signal classification in terms of modulation and medium access control technology. The foundations of this work lie in the intersection of statistical signal processing and hypothesis testing, random matrix theory, and Markov modeling.

Spatio-temporal spectrum sensing provide a much richer set of information and open up a wide range of secondary application opportunities that can leverage the RF information gathered. These areas include 1) the wireless communications infrastructure, in which throughput, capacity, and quality of service are all directly dependent on the ability to accurately characterize the RF environment, 2) environmental monitoring, which increasingly involves large networks of sensors that will need to efficiently communicate information in an increasingly complex and crowded spectrum, and 3) defense and national security, where the ability to rapidly and accurately identify the location and behavior of emitters leads directly to a host of critically important and tangible benefits both in terms of safety and mission success.
